block.p: What does a busboy do? ''He sets the table (often incorrectly),'' say Pamela Hillings and Phyllis Hillings in ''Manners in a Minute: Dining'' (Perrin & Kabel Fine Printworks, $15.95).
This slender booklet in a beribboned folder packs just about everything into its 23 no-nonsense pages that you need to know about correct dining and entertaining at home and in restaurants.
What does a busboy do? ''He sets the table (often incorrectly),'' say Pamela Hillings and Phyllis Hillings in ''Manners in a Minute: Dining'' (Perrin & Kabel Fine Printworks, $15.95).
This slender booklet in a beribboned folder packs just about everything into its 23 no-nonsense pages that you need to know about correct dining and entertaining at home and in restaurants.
Think the authors are tough on busboys? Describing the American style of eating, they say this:

''After cutting one bite only, the knife is set down on the plate with the sharp edge facing center of plate. The fork is transferred to the right hand, food is speared with the fork and carried to the mouth with the fork tines up. Process is repeated. And repeated. And repeated.''
On the other hand, mastering the Continental method, in which the knife is held in the right hand and the fork always in the left, makes one look ''sophisticated, well traveled and rich,'' they add.
How to pronounce and eat various foods, and how to toast and tip are among their helpful tidbits.
Charts show how a table should be set.
The booklet is sold at A Perfect Setting, 140 Atlantic Avenue, Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 222-1868.
